PRESS PUBLICATION COMPLAINT BY MEMBER FOR HONG LIM
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: On the 23rd day of December, 1960, the then hon. Member for Hong Lim drew my attention to that day's Straits Times containing what he described as an account of that day's proceedings, that is to say, the proceedings in the matter of the motion moved by the Deputy Prime Minister in relation to that Member.

Column: 888



    The article in question was captioned. "Ong must cite law to back his motion". The Member referred to two paragraphs therein and invited my opinion as to whether - to quote his words - "any of the passages referred to is a matter which is sub judice".

    I then expressed the opinion that there was no matter which could be considered sub judice at that moment, the expression "sub judice" being used with reference to a court of law. Hon. Members will of course know, for example, that under Standing Order No. 19 relating to the contents of questions, no question may be asked which reflects on the decision of a court of law and no question shall be asked on any matter which is sub judice; and again under Standing Order No. 46 relating to the contents of speeches, reference cannot be made to any matter which is sub judice except by means of or in the course of consideration of a Bill when reference may be made, but only in such a way as will not, in the opinion of the Speaker or Chairman, prejudice the interests of parties thereto. I might add that in the application of those Standing Orders the term "sub judice" has been construed to have reference to matters pending in a court of law and in a Commission of Inquiry.

    The then Member for Hong Lim, however, in response to my enquiry, stated that he wished to raise his point as a matter of privilege, drawing my attention to the fact that the report was contained not only in the Straits Times but also in other newspapers. I do not think that the fact that the same report or article is contained in more than one newspaper could make any difference to a ruling as to whether there has been any breach of privilege.

    The passages quoted by the then Member for Hong Lim as being in breach of privilege of this Assembly are-

    Firstly:

    "This right has been admitted in the case of the House of Commons and in all Legislatures patterned after it."

The right referred to has reference to the right mentioned in the article in the two

Column: 889

passages immediately preceding the passage quoted. These two passages read as follows:-

    "Mr Ong's motion not only asks the House to rescind the Speaker's ruling but also claims that the Assembly has no powers either to condemn him or seek his suspension if he does not apologise or repeat outside the Assembly the "malicious falsehoods" he is accused of having made in the Assembly.

    It, in effect, challenges the constitutional principle that the Legislature has the inherent right, as stated in Standing Order 56, of "proceeding against any member according to any resolution of the Assembly."

    Secondly, that is to say, the second passage quoted by the then Member for Hong Lim is as follows:-

    "Last Monday, the Speaker ruled that under Standing Orders the Assembly had powers to discuss the motion and, if the evidence warranted it, to find the member guilty of `dishonourable conduct'.

    He also said that the Assembly had inherent powers, should a member be found guilty, to suspend or even expel him."

    In regard to the first passage, it is apparent that it merely purported to be an analysis of the legal position which in fact had been urged by the Deputy Prime Minister in his speech delivered when he moved the motion, as is apparent in the next passage in the article in question which reads as follows:-

    "Dr Toh, in his speech on Monday, had cited cases to show that the Singapore Assembly had these rights too."

    In regard to the second passage, it appears to be a paraphrase of what I myself said, albeit not exactly a complete or accurate paraphrase. The passage has been taken out of context and must be considered in the light of the following paragraph which reads:-

    "However, he expressed doubts as to what extent the extreme powers of expulsion and suspension could be exercised by the Assembly."

    If the then Member for Hong Lim in drawing my attention to the passages quoted by him and by using the term "sub judice" sought to infer that the passages are in the nature of comment calculated to prejudice the proceedings pending on the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister, then I am bound to say that I disagree; I take the view that there is nothing in those passages, more especially when not read out of context, which can be said to have that effect.

Column: 890



    This must not be taken to mean that I am ruling that any person who publishes any matter which is prejudicial to proceedings pending in the Assembly must necessarily be in breach of the privileges of the Assembly. Such a publication must, to my mind, first fall within the mischief of the Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance, 1955, which in section 24 specifically makes the publication of certain statements and writings an offence.

    In the event, therefore, I cannot say that there has been prima facie any breach of privilege in relation to the matters raised by the then Member for Hong Lim and do not therefore propose to take any further action in the matter.

PRESS PUBLICATION STATEMENT BY WORKERS PARTY
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: My attention has been drawn to a statement purported to be issued by the chairman of the Workers Party and published in the Straits Times of Saturday, December 24th, 1960. The publication reads as follows:

STATEMENT BY WORKERS PARTY


    SINGAPORE. Fri.- The Chairman of the Workers Party, Mr David Marshall, today issued this statement:

    "The first meeting of the new executive committee of the Workers Party repeats that the Workers Party is not associated with Mr Ong Eng Guan and had never been associated with Mr Ong, but expresses its sympathy and respect for the heroic effort of Mr Ong in struggling against the attempt of the P.A.P. Government to silence him and nullify the choice of the people of Hong Lim."'

    Hon. Members will recollect that on the 19th day of December, 1960, before the Deputy Prime Minister moved his motion in relation to the then Member for Hong Lim (Mr Ong Eng Guan), I went to some length to indicate that in my view, the motion should on no account be considered as a motion of censure and punishment moved in the interests of Government or of individuals in the Government, but should be treated

Column: 891

as a motion which related to the dignity and prestige of this Assembly and therefore was a motion in the interests of the Assembly as a whole. I went on to say that if the House was satisfied that the conduct of the hon. Member for Hong Lim was such as to be an affront to its own dignity and prestige in the sense inter alia that that conduct had brought discredit to the House as a whole - not merely to individual Members of the Government Parliamentary Party or indeed to any other Member of the House or to persons outside the House - then the House might feel itself justified in condemning or censuring the hon. Member for Hong Lim and thereafter in proceeding to consider what punishment, consonant with its powers, it should mete out to him. I finally stressed that the motion would and had to proceed as a motion which affected the House as a whole and which invited the House in the first instance to say whether its dignity and prestige had not been affronted by the conduct of the hon. Member for Hong Lim.

    In my view, therefore, the statement by the Chairman of the Workers Party is prima facie a gross, wilful and scandalous misrepresentation of the proceedings of this Assembly within the meaning of subsection (1) (c) of section 24 of the Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance, 1955, and I have accordingly referred the matter to the State Advocate-General for such action as he may think fit to take under that Ordinance.

PROPERTY TAX BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.48 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, I have the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation that this Bill be proceeded with. Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be read a Second time."

    Sir, the object of this Bill is to provide for the levy of a tax on immovable properties in lieu of rates leviable under the Municipal Ordinance and the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, as on integration of the City Council into the Central Government, it will be no longer proper to levy Local Government rates on lands and buildings, since these are made on the basis of services and utilities of equivalent value being provided from the revenue so obtained. It will be necessary, therefore, to introduce a new system of taxation to replace these rates.

    The present Bill follows closely the procedure laid down in the Local Government Ordinance for the assessment of annual value of property and collection of rates.

    At present, rates are collected for the City area under powers contained in the Local Government Ordinance and for the rural areas under the Municipal Ordinance. The consolidated rate payable in respect of properties in the City area is now 36 per cent and section 7 of the Property Tax Ordinance lays down that the property tax payable each year shall be at this same rate of 36 per cent.

    Some areas outside the City limits are, however, paying rates at less than 36 per cent applicable to the City area. It is intended to continue this practice of charging lower rates for rural areas and the first proviso to section 7 enables the Minister to direct that the rate or tax in such areas shall be such rate or rate less than 36 per cent.

    The property tax proposals for 1961 are briefly as follows.

    At present, properties within City limits are assessed at 36 per cent and properties in the rural areas are assessed at 14 per cent, 18 per cent, 20 per cent, 23 per cent, or 36 per cent consolidated

Column: 894

rates. Instead of this multiplicity of rates, there will be only three rates of Property Tax for occupied lands, which will be 36 per cent, 27 per cent and 18 per cent.

    Properties at present paying 36 per cent rates will continue to pay 36 per cent Property Tax on the annual value ascribed to the property. There are certain areas which previously were outside the City limits but which have been brought into the City area by the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, as defined in the First Schedule to the Ordinance. They comprise largely the areas at Pasir Panjang, Buona Vista, Ulu Pandan, Holland Road and Ulu Kallang. These areas were assessed at 23 per cent when they were in the rural areas and the assessment of 23 per cent was continued, although they were brought into the City limits with the coming into force of the Local Government Ordinance. These areas will now pay the rate of 36 per cent instead of 23 per cent.

    There are also a number of housing estates in the rural areas which pay 23 per cent assessment. They are Adelphi Park, Sembawang Hill, Thomson Rise, Windsor Park, Serangoon Garden, Seletar Hill, Opera Estate, Spring and Bedok Estates, Hongkong Park, Bukit Timah Park and King Albert Park. These housing estates have enjoyed urban facilities as lighting, water, roads and so forth, and will therefore pay 36 per cent rate.

    The 27 per cent rate areas will include areas at present paying 19 per cent, 20 per cent and 23 per cent. These areas will include properties lying within-

    (i) ½ mile on either side of Bukit Timah Road from approximately 8 ½ m.s. and along Woodlands Road up to the Causeway;

    (ii) ½ mile radius of Nee Soon and Chong Pang Villages and ¼ mile on either side of Jalan Kayu;

    (iii) areas at Serangoon, Paya Lebar, Bedok, Changi and Loyang.

    The remaining parts of the Island were previously paying 14 per cent or 18 per cent. They will now be assessed at 18 per cent. These areas comprise-

Column: 895



    (i) the present undeveloped western portions of the Island, i.e., Jurong;

    (ii) the undeveloped northern and north-eastern parts comprising Bukit Panjang, Sembawang, Serangoon and Katong;

    (iii) some of the surrounding islands, i.e., Pulau Ubin, Pulau Tekong Kechil, Pulau Tekong Besar, Pulau Blakang Mati, Pulau Bukom, Pulau Bukom Kechil and a few other islands.

    The above rates will be payable on houses or occupied lands. The rate for vacant lands is at present 36 per cent for properties in the City area and this 36 per cent for vacant lands will apply to the 36 per cent areas for 1961.

    The rate for vacant lands in the 27 per cent and 18 per cent areas will be at 18 per cent and 12 per cent respectively.

    Details of the proposals will be gazetted shortly and a plan will be made available for inspection showing the rates applicable to the whole Island.

    These proposals are not final and the public will be given an opportunity up to 31st March, 1961, to make representations regarding the inclusion of any particular area or locality in one of the three rates of tax proposed.

    I have stated in my Budget Statement that the present practice of assessing owner-occupied properties on favourable terms is irregular and that it is intended to stop this practice. However, in order not to penalise owner-occupiers of small properties, the rates of taxation will be fixed at less than the general rate. It will obviously take some time for the owner-occupied houses to be re-valued at the proper values. Until the re-valuation of these properties has been completed, owner-occupiers will continue to pay property rates at the proposed rates on present values. Similarly, provision is also made in respect of industrial premises in order to ensure that industrial undertakings are not hampered through the operation of the Bill.

Column: 896



    It is proposed to withdraw the exemption of land and buildings used as public burial and burning grounds and certain institutions fostering the arts and sciences which are at present exempted from payment of rates under the Local Government Ordinance or the Municipal Ordinance on the grounds that these organisations are run on commercial lines and they charge fees or levies for their services. However, provision is made for exemption of deserving cases of this nature and of buildings used exclusively for purposes conducive to social development. Provision is also made to allow statutory bodies to pay half-yearly to the Government an equitable sum in lieu of property tax.

    It is proposed to make it mandatory for any person who owns property which has not been assessed to give notice thereof to the Chief Assessor. It will also be mandatory for him to notify the Chief Assessor when a building ceases to be occupied by the owner thereof and is let. Because the tax is a tax on the ownership of property irrespective of whether it is occupied or not, refunds of tax for "letted" buildings which have become unoccupied during the tax year will cease.

    Special provisions have been made for assessment of taxes on new buildings, buildings which have been rebuilt or enlarged, properties assessed for the first time, and properties which should have been assessed for rates under the Municipal Ordinance or the Local Government Ordinance prior to the coming into operation of this Ordinance but have not been so assessed. It is provided that in all these cases the tax shall be payable from the date of completion of the building or in the case of land from such date, not being more than six years prior to the date on which the property is first assessed, as may be determined by the Comptroller. In cases where a building ceases to be occupied by the owner and is let or where the rent thereof is increased, the tax payable from the date of such letting or increase of rent is to be calculated on the basis of a revised value which may subsequently be ascribed to such building. Provision has

Column: 897

also been made for any annual value or revised annual value ascribed to a property during the second half of any year to remain the same for the ensuing year.

    The procedure for hearing of objections on assessments has been completely revised by the establishment of an impartial Valuation Review Board and for appeals to the High Court. The Bill provides for temporary deletion from the Valuation List of properties in respect of which notice of objection to revision of annual value has been received and for interim payment on due date of taxes on such properties based on current valuation pending adjudication of the objection to the proposed revision.

    In conclusion, I wish to say that it is not intended to levy Education and Improvement rates of 4 per cent each, and that these two sections in the Education and Planning Ordinance will be repealed.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.03 p.m.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are one or two aspects of the Bill upon which I wish to touch. The first, Mr Speaker, Sir, which I think is a very serious one, is the Minister's statement that in future it is not proposed to give refunds in respect of unoccupied property. And the basis for the change in law, it would appear, according to the Minister, is that as this is considered to be a property tax, therefore the mere owning of the property should attract the tax, whether or not the property, in fact, produces any income. That, Mr Speaker, Sir, is a very serious statement for the Minister for Finance to make. I personally cannot see any difference, from the taxing point of view, whether property is immovable or movable. The Minister for Finance says that if anybody in Singapore should be so foolish as to put his surplus money which is lying in the bank without earning any income, on a piece of land which, through circumstances beyond

Column: 898

his control, ceases to produce any income, then that property is still liable to tax. Contra - if he keeps his money lying idle in the bank not earning any income, as the Minister has not yet decided to introduce a capital tax, he would be exempt from taxation in so far as his idle money is concerned. What then is the difference between tile two! If a man shakes a leg a bit and wants to help me State and himself, anti invests his money anti puts it to some profitable use, then me Minister says, "Because it is a property tax, I must tax you on the property even though it does not earn any income." Supposing a person owns 10 houses in, say, North Bridge Road, and if a slump were to come - it might yet come within the time of the present Government, some say it is already here - then that person who has 10 houses unlet would have to pay tax at 36 per cent. Where does he get his money from to pay this 36 per cent? He will end up in ruination, and so will the property market. And it the property market is brought to ruination, Mr Speaker, Sir, me economy of Singapore also would to a large extent be ruined.

    Now, I would ask the Government to reconsider this proposition very seriously; even the principle is unacceptable. I can see no justification for saying that merely because you own property, you should pay tax on it. I think the property should be put to some use in respect of which the State is providing services. That is the basic proposition on which municipal assessments are levied, Mr Speaker, Sir, and not because you own property. The mere owning of property, from a municipal point of view, does not attract rates. But if the property is of such a nature that it attracts municipal services to itself, or the preservation of which depends on the provision of adequate municipal services, then in return for those services a rate is levied. That is the basis on which municipal rates are levied. The Property Tax says:

    `An Ordinance to provide for the levy of a tax on immovable properties in lieu of the rates previously leviable ...'.

Column: 899

Apparently the Government has forgotten the basis on which this rate was levied by the City Council and rural authorities. All they are interested in is the monies which they can collect, not the purpose for which the monies are collected.

    If a house falls vacant, Mr Speaker, Sir, then it is not using municipal services -it is not using water; it is not using light; it is not using sewerage facilities. What are the facilities which the Government is providing in respect of that house on which they claim a 36 per cent tax? It is inequitable; it is scandalous. If that sort of thing is allowed to come about, Mr Speaker, Sir, there will be no building estates built in Singapore. The Government has already stated, in the building sector anyway, that it is both an enterprise between the Government and the private sector in order that adequate housing might be provided for Singapore in future years. Government hopes to build 9,000 houses next year. I do not think they will, but if they do build, it will be a very good effort. But according to plans, we need at least 15,000 to 20,000 houses per year if we want to provide for the increasing population, not to catch up, but merely to provide for the increasing population. If Government introduces legislation which is going to not only discourage but also stop private development then I cannot see how it is going to bring adequate housing accommodation to Singapore. My experience of Government is that they say one thing and they do another. They say they want to encourage housing. They say, "We want to encourage people to build houses." I ask the Minister for Finance: does he, in all seriousness, think that this omission of the refund of tax now possible under the Local Government Ordinance, whereby a person whose house is unoccupied can go to him and claim a refund, is going to help housing projects in Singapore?

    Let us take a person, or a company, who has 20 acres of land and who wants to develop it. Under present conditions it is very difficult to envisage or to forecast

Column: 900

whether all those houses built on the land would be bought or taken up by persons who want to buy houses. Let us assume that that person is a venturesome sort of developer, and he develops. If he sells as much as 50 per cent of the houses to begin with he is lucky, Mr Speaker; the rest of the 50 per cent lie vacant and idle. As soon as he receives a certificate of occupation from the relevant authority, the vacant houses will attract property tax. What happens to the developer? He faces ruination. He is paying a tax of 36 per cent on the balance of the developed property. And what is the annual value under the Property Tax? The annual value, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the rent at which it may reasonably be expected to let from year to year. So it attracts tax at once and the position is that he will have to contribute 36 per cent to the Government by way of tax until such time as he has disposed of his property. This is not the Ordinance, Mr Speaker, Sir, that is going to help bring a building boom to Singapore. If anything it is going to help kill it. The P.A.P. Government has nearly killed the building industry, and this Bill will surely help to put the industry into a coffin and place it well and truly seven feet under the ground.

    Mr Byrne: Six or seven?

    Mr Rajah: An extra one foot for the P.A.P. Government! So that is the position which will ensue if this Bill is passed without the provision which is now already contained in the Local Government Ordinance. Other than that, Mr Speaker, it is merely a duplication of the existing provisions in the Local Government Ordinance and the Municipal Ordinance, except that it gives the Minister a lot of powers personally, which the Local Government Ordinance did not give to the City Council as such. If the powers are used wisely by the Minister, well and good. But if the Minister does not use those powers wisely, but uses them in an oppressive sort of way, then there again it is going to be a bad thing. Mr Speaker, I am against the policy - that Ministers should be allowed wide powers in respect of which the public at

Column: 901

large do not know what line each Minister would adopt. The provisions should be embodied in the Ordinance itself.

    Now, immovable property and investments, Mr Speaker, are matters in respect of which the investing public must be satisfied that the position will be stable for a number of years. If exemptions of this nature are to be left to the individual discretion of the Minister, I am suggesting to the Minister for Finance that that is not the best way to inspire confidence in the investing public. Under the Municipal Ordinance, Mr Speaker, Sir, there were circumstances where areas which were not given all the municipal services were not liable to the complete 36 per cent rates. I hope the Minister will keep that in mind when he considers these various areas from the point of view of the varying rates which he intends to tax.

    There are certain areas in Singapore, Mr Speaker, Sir, which do not have a supply of electricity. There are other areas which do not have a supply of water. There are yet other areas which do not have the sewerage system installed. These are all municipal facilities in respect of which this 36 per cent is being levied by the Government. How the Minister is going to sort out these things area by area, I do not know. But I do hope that when the Minister does make these levies, he will see that he holds a balance between all the areas, and that in respect of each of those areas which does not have all the municipal facilities, an adequately reduced tax is imposed.

    The only other innovation to the Property Tax Bill which was not in the Local Government Ordinance is the provision whereby industrial premises could also be exempt from the 36 per cent taxation as envisaged for the rest of the properties. I do not propose to touch upon this matter, because my colleague, the Member for Cairnhill, will deal with it. But I do wish to press upon the Minister for Finance this position: that I think this Bill, which proposes to levy a tax on unoccupied property which had previously been rented, Mr

Column: 902

Speaker, Sir, is going to have the certain effect of not encouraging builders to build in Singapore.

3.15 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the Budget speech, the Minister for Finance stated that in regard to rural areas, it was not proposed to increase the rates other than where there had been improvements, such as roads, lighting, water and electricity. But in his speech this afternoon, he has told us that at the present time there are five types of rates - 14 per cent, 18 per cent, 20 per cent, 23 per cent and 36 per cent, and it is proposed to reduce this number to three - 36 per cent, 27 per cent and 18 per cent. Therefore, by a mere manipulation of reducing five types of rates to three, those that are in the lower rates become affected. In the case of 14 per cent rate, therefore, there is already a proposed increase of 4 per cent. In the case of the 20 per cent and 23 per cent rates, there is therefore a proposed increased of 7 per cent and 4 per cent respectively. Over and above that, the Minister is proposing that where there are housing estates developed in the rural areas, these will be rated at 36 per cent.
